title.narrative: 3.3. Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) & ENVIRONMENTAL SUSTAINABILITY

description.narrative: By 2021, there will have been capacity-building of the State and society to rate national policies for water and sanitation in rural areas and manage the risk of disasters based on the implementation of comprehensive environmental management models in rural, indigenous and peri-urban areas, for the priority territories., which contributes to Child Health, Environmental Sustainability, Hygiene, Other Cross-Sectoral Programme Areas, Prevention And Response Services For Violence Against Children, Sanitation, Sanitation (Covid), Wash And Emergencies, Wash In Schools And Ecd Centres, Wash â€“ General, Water, Water Supply. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2021, children exposed to concerns related to gender, ethnicity, area of residence, living conditions or differences in skills will live in safe environments and have full access to relevant and quality registration, health, nutrition, care, education, water, sanitation and hygiene services that promote their full development.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2021, there will have been capacity-building of the State and society to rate national policies for water and sanitation in rural areas and manage the risk of disasters based on the implementation of comprehensive environmental management models in rural, indigenous and peri-urban areas, for the priority territories.

description.narrative: UNICEF has successfully prototyped scalable innovative WASH solutions in dispersed and vulnerable rural communities, which have fed into national sanitation policies. UNICEF leads the WASH Working Group on disaster risk management, where UNICEF is creating a pathway to bring together the WASH governing body, the WASH regulator and other WASH stakeholders to develop ways of working on Disaster Risk Management nationwide. With UNICEF's support, the Ministry of Environment (MINAM) organized a youth and adolescent-focused event Let's Talk for Climate Change, which informed the Climate Change Act Guidelines. The MINAM presented the event at COP 25. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:31/12/2019

title.narrative: Number of national and regional plans and programs, including appropriate and sustainable water supply and sanitation models for rural communities.
Number of prioritized local governments that implement appropriate and sustainable water supply and sanitation models in homes, health and education facilities in rural areas.
Number of targeted population provided with hygiene kits or key hygiene items in the reporting year [COVID]
Number of policies, plans and programs regarding environmental protection, including the child rights-based approach.
Number of communities certified free of open defecation that integrate standards for protection of girls and women as a result of UNICEF and partner support (leveraged/indirect)

Number of intrasectoral , intersectoral and intergovernmental disaster risk management spaces and linkage mechanisms, at a national and priority territories level, that include a children and adolescents rights approach.
Application of a progressive standard model in the Ministry of Education (MINEDU) safe school registration system.

baseline.value: There is not official information. Safe schools registration system development in progress.

target.value: 2021:There is an official information system based in infraestructure standards, environment analysis, mitigation measures and a Disaster Risk Reduction Plan.

actual.value: 2019:Technical assistance for updating, adjusting and applying the Safe Schools Index tool to assess the safety conditions of an educational institution in the event of an adverse emergency or disaster, in the prioritized territories and then extending it to the national level, based on national sectoral
